avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow are to be assessed with care and prudence.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The wind slabs of the weekend can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example.
Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach large size in isolated cases. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
In all altitude zones hardly any more moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as the temperature drops.

snowpackStructure.comment: In the last few days clearly visible wind slabs formed above the tree line. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. As a consequence of falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Wind slabs can as before be released, mostly by large loads and reach medium size. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular above the tree line, and on very steep shady slopes. Here avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases.
As the temperature drops hardly any more natural moist avalanches are to be expected.

snowpackStructure.comment: The wind slabs of the weekend remain in some cases prone to triggering on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack here. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. As a consequence of falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate.
